Handcrafted CSS

I'm going to review a few of the best practices I learned from reading Handcrafted CSS: More Bulletproof Web Design by Dan Cederholm. Note: This article is not meant to be walkthrough.

Assignment: Work with floats to create a menu with optimal markup. Keep usability in mind.

Example 1

  • Latte $2.79
  • Cappuccino $2.99
  • Espresso $2.00
  • Half-caf, latte (with a twist of lemon) $10.49

Dan recommended making the entire row clickable including link titles and prices. Why you ask?

Fitts's law: a model of human movement primarily used in humanâ€“computer interaction that predicts that the time required to rapidly move to a target area is a function of the distance to the target and the size of the target.

So by increasing the clickable area, this will help increase usability and make for a better user experience. Sounds awesome!

I'm already familiar with display: block but I will need to clear my floats when using block-level elements within containers.

overflow: hidden: a method of self-clearing any floats that occur within the container element.

Here is the CSS I added to my list item's a tag:

ul.lst li a { display: block; overflow: hidden; padding: 3%; }

  • Latte $2.79
  • Cappuccino $2.99
  • Espresso $2.00
  • Half-caf, latte (with a twist of lemon) $10.49

Looks ok, but I can still make improvements. I need a border to visually separate each list item and a hover color to show the current selection.

Example 2

Time to make those improvements by adding a bottom border and a hover to my CSS:

ul.lst li a { border-bottom: 1px solid #ddd; display: block; overflow: hidden; padding: 3%; }

ul.lst li:hover { background: #fff8dc; }

  • Latte $2.79
  • Cappuccino $2.99
  • Espresso $2.00
  • Half-caf, latte (with a twist of lemon) $10.49

Hover over the different list items. Almost there, but I still have two issues. Notice the double border at the very bottom? Also, I want to add a background color to every other row. This should help improve readability.

:nth-of-type(n)

I could create an even and odd class for my background and then apply it to my HTML. By using the :nth-of-type(n) selector I can achieve these results without all the extra markup:

The :nth-of-type(n) selector matches every element that is the nth child, of a particular type, of its parent. N can be a number, a keyword, or a formula.

Just what I need. These are the two keywords I will use:

nth-of-type(even)
nth-of-type(odd)

Odd and even are keywords that can be used to match child elements whose index is odd or even. Note: the index of the first child is 1.

Now I can set the background color for every other row with no extra markup:

ul.lst li:nth-of-type(even) { background: #f8f8f8; }

Next, I need to remove the bottom border on the last row to avoid double borders:

:nth-last-of-type(n) selector matches every element that is the nth child, of a particular type, of its parent, counting from the last child.

Here is what the CSS looks like:

ul.lst li:nth-last-of-type(1) a { border-bottom: 0; }

Example 3: Final results

  • Cappuccino $2.99
  • Espresso $2.00
  • Half-caf, latte (with a twist of lemon) $10.49
